Media: The New York Times
Review: The pulse-racing revival of the musical ''Chicago,'' involves a cast of top-flight artists perfectly mated to their parts and some of the sexiest, most sophisticated dancing seen on Broadway in years...The America portrayed onstage may be a vision of hell, but the way it's being presented flies us right into musical heaven.

Media: Talkin' Broadway
Review: Chicago is as good now as it's ever been--a heartening experience, a life-affirming dedication to the magic and art of theatre, and something that absolutely should not be missed. Though all shows must eventually close, the glory and genius of Chicago should be celebrated while it's here, and with any luck, it will still be gracing and energizing Broadway for many years to come.

Media: Theatermania
Review: Cynics predicted that the big-screen opus would mean the end of the show's Gotham run, but the opposite has occurred for this Encores!-originated revival...the show is now an SRO proposition. During intermission, audience members may be heard debating the comparative merits of the live and canned treatments.

Media: CurtainUp
Review: What it's all about: 'murder, greed, corruption, violence, exploitation, adultery and treachery.' Of course what it's also about is sensational dancing, singing, acting...and, fun! No razzle-dazzle mechanical props, just the razzle-dazzle of a company of gifted performers delivering two hours and twenty minutes of show-stopping numbers.

Media: Theatermania
Review: Broadway's busiest revolving door, better known as the nearly 10-year-old revival of Chicago, has someone new passing through: the R&B superstar with the single moniker of Usher...while he's a good two or three decades younger than most of his predecessors, the tuxedo fits decently enough.

Media: The Associated Press
Review: A lot of Broadway musicals don't age very well, but the long-running revival of 'Chicago' seems to have discovered the fountain of youth. The score's catchy melodies are potent, toe-tapping reminders of music from the late 1920s, while the lyrics are snappy, pointed and often very funny.

Media: Theatermania
Review: The Broadway revival of John Kander and Fred Ebb's Chicago, may be on the verge of celebrating its 15th anniversary, but one could hardly tell the production has recently entered the upper echelon of long-running shows on Broadway. There's a crispness to the entire piece of Chicago, that belies its age.

Media: OoCities
Review: The stunning revival of Chicago that just opened on Broadway ought to win over any doubters. Chicago hasn't merely aged well; it has come of age...A show that doesn't just give us the old razzle-dazzle; it glows.

Media: New York Daily News
Review: Because the revival of  Chicago  is so wildly entertaining, I'm hesitant to call it important, always an ugly adjective for a reviewer to use...What makes this revival important, is that it reminds us that musicals are about songs and performers, not scenery. When you have material and performances as dynamic as this, you don't need chandeliers.

Media: Variety
Review: If the Kander & Ebb style can be described in one word, it<U+2019>s showstopper. And though their detractors might argue that the tenacity can be wearying, they<U+2019>ll find scant support for that position in <U+201C>Chicago.<U+201D> Even in a concert staging, the momentum starts high and gets higher.

Media: Hello Beautiful
Review: Starring alongside Broadway legend, Amra-Faye Wright, Brandy held her own. Her voice sends goosebumps up your spine, or could it be that you know every woman in the cast has killed someone...  Brandy was lovable as the fiendish, but coy criminal. Her acting was spot-on and her voice was the cherry on top. 'Chicago' is exciting, sexy and absolutely ridiculous and taking that ride with Brandy was one of the most enjoyable Broadway experiences I<U+2019>ve had in a long time.

Review: See it if you're interested in the classic storyline, and/or you're on a $25 budget and are okay with standing room tickets
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you're looking to be dazzled by choreography.=Also As a dancer myself, and a fan of the movie, I was very excited to see a fantastically choreographed musical, and I was extremely disappointed. The choreography in the movie was much more exciting, and this was very understated. Specifically, the choreography for Cell Block Tango was outright lazy and consisted mainly of the girls running around chairs set up in the middle of the stage, reminiscent of a scantily-clad game of musical chairs. The redeeming number of the show was the original Bob Fosse choreography used for the final number. It would've been better if the two actresses could have stayed together, a mistake many amateur dancers would never dare to make in front of such a large crowd. Overall, I'm glad I only paid $25 to be so underwhelmed, and I would recommend skipping this for a more entertaining show....<U+00A0>Read more Read less

Review (Don't): Don't see it if ... if you don't like cynicism or satire=Also The popularity of this inexpensive revival is a bit surprising... though I suppose when you don't have a set or any period costumes your weekly nut is relatively small.CHICAGO is a terrific musical, unfortunately this overrated revival gives no sense of time or place and I'm afraid has become a model on how to present a musical on the cheap. Of course the score is still there, and Ann Reinking's choreography in the  Fosse style  is very entertaining; but about the best I can say for the revival is that it's better than the movie. I hope someday to see a true revival of the show: one that honors the original subtitle  A Musical Vaudeville. ...<U+00A0>Read more Read less
